{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3524250,"name":"","username":"LHACK4142","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T00:39:38.312Z","cooked":"

To avoid tipping, if necessary, I hope to use a dynamic acceleration limit on the robot‚Äôs drivetrain. It would probably just set the acceleration limit to some function of the elevator‚Äôs height.

Currently, we‚Äôre using SlewRateLimiter to limit our acceleration. However, slewratelimiter doesn‚Äôt seem to allow you to change its rate limits after creation, and I don‚Äôt think we can create a new SlewRateLimiter object every cycle because you then lose its memory. We could also use maxmotion velocity control, but this would require configuring the sparks every cycle, which feels sketchy.

How do you all do it?

The simplest way is to implement the basic physics equation Vf = Vi +at. Vf is the output, Vi is the initial speed, a is your input acceleration, and t is usually 0.02s. (Loop time of 50Hz). It could be generalized as the delta speed change is just =a*t.

More advanced, YAGSL does have a calculation to estimate your CG and limit your acceleration. You will have to estimate where your mass is on the robot and pass it in as a Matter array. But it also does what you want (and implements the equation above). Note there isn‚Äôt more documentation past this.

LHACK4142:

However, slewratelimiter doesn‚Äôt seem to allow you to change its rate limits after creation, and I don‚Äôt think we can create a new SlewRateLimiter object every cycle because you then lose its memory

We are creating a new slew rate limiter only when the elevator height changes, its not perfect but it is working so far. The answer above is how you would create a continuous acceleration limit.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T14:20:15.418Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":55.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":491287,"topic_slug":"dynamic-acceleration-limits-how-do-you-implement-them","display_username":"Owen Busler","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23320,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dynamic-acceleration-limits-how-do-you-implement-them/491287/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3524832,"name":"Matthew Milunic","username":"mathum","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/8baadc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T16:18:03.597Z","cooked":"

We were thinking about this a lot for our robot, at least from a theoretical side. Ideally, it would be impossible to tip the robot due to acceleration limits. One technically possible thing would be checking your gyro to see if you start to tip up, and if you do, limiting your acceleration to zero in that direction until you stop tipping, maybe even accelerating slightly in reverse. This would probably maximize your acceleration every single time, but might not be very stable or could be jittery (we never tried it out).

The solution our team ended up going with is using the acceleration limit calculated from the COM height as Steve_Carmain mentioned, but also limiting the robot speed so that stopping time always stays below a certain amount of time. This is to avoid a scenario where the robot is traveling very fast, puts its arm up, and suddenly takes forever to stop, and could potentially be a bit unsafe. We calculate the max speed as \text{max speed} = (\text{acceleration}) \cdot (\text{stopping time}).

We also restrict our elevator to only travel upwards once the robot is below the commanded ‚Äúmax speed‚Äù.

You can directly configure the ramp rate of the motor (closed loop, open loop). I don‚Äôt think it will be a problem to configure it each cycle, but it‚Äôs also not like the elevator is constantly moving all the time. Also, you could ‚Äúslice‚Äù the elevator into a few parts and reconfigure the ramp rate only when the elevator‚Äôs height changes between these parts.

Here is a version of SlewRateLimiter that takes an acceleration supplier. I haven‚Äôt tested it on a real robot, but we have tested it in a simulator. Famous last words, but since it is a revision of SlewRateLimiter from WPILIB it ‚Ä¶should‚Ä¶ work. I would PR it into WPILIB but I don‚Äôt have a working build environment for WPILIB‚Ä¶

github.com

hollisms/GraphCommandExample/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/util/SlewRateLimiterWithSupplier.java

// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.

package frc.util;

import java.util.function.DoubleSupplier;

import edu.wpi.first.math.MathSharedStore;
import edu.wpi.first.math.MathUtil;

/**
 * A class that limits the rate of change of an input value. Useful for
 * implementing voltage,
 * setpoint, and/or output ramps. A slew-rate limit is most appropriate when the
 * quantity being
 * controlled is a velocity or a voltage; when controlling a position, consider
 * using a {@link
 * edu.wpi.first.math.trajectory.TrapezoidProfile} instead.
 */
